label: chapter_4_Exception_Handling_.pdf
title: Introduction to Java Exception Handling & The Java Exception Hierarchy and Types & Blocks, Clauses, and Keywords & The finally Block and Throwing Exceptions & Stack Unwinding and Throwable Information & Chained and Custom Exception Types & Assertions, Multi-catch, and try-with-resources

questions.text: What is the definition of an exception in Java as described in the text?

choices.label: A syntax error that prevents the code from compiling.
choices.text: A syntax error that prevents the code from compiling.

choices.label: An indication of a problem that occurs during a program’s execution.
choices.text: An indication of a problem that occurs during a program’s execution.

choices.label: A method that specifically handles arithmetic errors.
choices.text: A method that specifically handles arithmetic errors.

choices.label: A logic error that always causes the computer to crash.
choices.text: A logic error that always causes the computer to crash.

questions.explanation: An exception is an indication of a problem that occurs during a program's execution, allowing for robust and fault-tolerant program design.

questions.text: What information is typically included in a 'stack trace' when an exception occurs?

choices.label: The name of the exception and the method-call stack at the time of the error.
choices.text: The name of the exception and the method-call stack at the time of the error.

choices.label: A list of all variables currently in memory.
choices.text: A list of all variables currently in memory.

choices.label: The compiled bytecode of the failing method.
choices.text: The compiled bytecode of the failing method.

choices.label: The operating system's kernel log.
choices.text: The operating system's kernel log.

questions.explanation: A stack trace includes the name of the exception, a descriptive message, and the call chain that led to the exception, helping developers debug the program.

questions.text: In Java integer arithmetic, what happens when an attempt is made to divide by zero?

choices.label: The program returns the value 'Infinity'.
choices.text: The program returns the value 'Infinity'.

choices.label: The program returns the value 'NaN'.
choices.text: The program returns the value 'NaN'.

choices.label: An ArithmeticException is thrown.
choices.text: An ArithmeticException is thrown.

choices.label: An InputMismatchException is thrown.
choices.text: An InputMismatchException is thrown.

questions.explanation: Java does not allow division by zero in integer arithmetic and throws an ArithmeticException. Floating-point arithmetic, however, would result in Infinity or NaN.

choices.label: The numerator is assigned a value of 0.
choices.text: The numerator is assigned a value of 0.

choices.label: An InputMismatchException is thrown.
choices.text: An InputMismatchException is thrown.

choices.label: A NoSuchElementException is thrown.
choices.text: A NoSuchElementException is thrown.

choices.label: The code fails to compile.
choices.text: The code fails to compile.

questions.explanation: An InputMismatchException occurs when Scanner method nextInt receives a string that does not represent a valid integer.

questions.text: According to the 'termination model' of exception handling, where does control resume after an exception is handled by a catch block?

choices.label: At the statement immediately following the throw point.
choices.text: At the statement immediately following the throw point.

choices.label: At the beginning of the try block.
choices.text: At the beginning of the try block.

choices.label: After the last catch block (or finally block if present).
choices.text: After the last catch block (or finally block if present).

choices.label: The program always terminates immediately.
choices.text: The program always terminates immediately.

questions.explanation: Under the termination model, once an exception is handled, control resumes after the last catch block because the try block has expired.

questions.text: Which class is the direct superclass of both Exception and Error?

choices.label: Object
choices.text: Object

choices.label: Throwable
choices.text: Throwable

choices.label: RuntimeException
choices.text: RuntimeException

choices.label: StandardException
choices.text: StandardException

questions.explanation: Class Throwable is the superclass of both Exception and Error, and only Throwable objects can be used with the exception-handling mechanism.

questions.text: Which of the following describes 'unchecked exceptions'?

choices.label: Exceptions that must be listed in a method's throws clause.
choices.text: Exceptions that must be listed in a method's throws clause.

choices.label: Subclasses of Exception but not RuntimeException.
choices.text: Subclasses of Exception but not RuntimeException.

choices.label: Direct or indirect subclasses of RuntimeException and Error.
choices.text: Direct or indirect subclasses of RuntimeException and Error.

choices.label: Exceptions that are checked by the compiler at compile-time.
choices.text: Exceptions that are checked by the compiler at compile-time.

questions.explanation: Unchecked exceptions include subclasses of RuntimeException and Error. The compiler does not force the programmer to catch or declare them.

questions.text: What is the 'catch-or-declare' requirement in Java?

choices.label: A rule stating all exceptions must be caught using a try-catch block.
choices.text: A rule stating all exceptions must be caught using a try-catch block.

choices.label: A requirement that checked exceptions must be either caught or declared in a throws clause.
choices.text: A requirement that checked exceptions must be either caught or declared in a throws clause.

choices.label: A requirement that all methods must return a value or throw an error.
choices.text: A requirement that all methods must return a value or throw an error.

choices.label: A rule that prevents more than one catch block per try block.
choices.text: A rule that prevents more than one catch block per try block.

questions.explanation: The Java compiler enforces a catch-or-declare requirement for checked exceptions, ensuring they are either handled locally or passed up the call stack.

questions.text: What happens if a catch block for a superclass type (e.g., Exception) is placed before a catch block for one of its subclasses (e.g., ArithmeticException)?

choices.label: The program will run normally and pick the most specific match.
choices.text: The program will run normally and pick the most specific match.

choices.label: The subclass catch block will execute if an exact match is found.
choices.text: The subclass catch block will execute if an exact match is found.

choices.label: A compilation error occurs.
choices.text: A compilation error occurs.

choices.label: The superclass catch block will be ignored.
choices.text: The superclass catch block will be ignored.

questions.explanation: Placing a superclass catch block before a subclass catch block results in a compilation error because the subclass block becomes unreachable.

questions.text: Which of the following is typically used for problems that are beyond the control of the application and from which it is usually not possible to recover?

choices.label: RuntimeException
choices.text: RuntimeException

choices.label: Exception
choices.text: Exception

choices.label: Error
choices.text: Error

choices.label: IOException
choices.text: IOException

questions.explanation: Class Error and its subclasses represent abnormal situations that happen in the JVM, and applications usually cannot recover from them.

questions.text: Where must the `throws` clause be located in a method declaration?

choices.label: Inside the method body, before the first statement.
choices.text: Inside the method body, before the first statement.

choices.label: Before the method's return type.
choices.text: Before the method's return type.

choices.label: After the method's parameter list and before its body.
choices.text: After the method's parameter list and before its body.

choices.label: Immediately following the class name.
choices.text: Immediately following the class name.

questions.explanation: The throws clause appears after the method's parameter list and before the method's body.

questions.text: Under what condition will a `finally` block NOT execute?

choices.label: When an exception is caught in a catch block.
choices.text: When an exception is caught in a catch block.

choices.label: When a return statement is executed in the try block.
choices.text: When a return statement is executed in the try block.

choices.label: When the application exits early via System.exit.
choices.text: When the application exits early via System.exit.

choices.label: When no exception occurs in the try block.
choices.text: When no exception occurs in the try block.

questions.explanation: The finally block will not execute if the application terminates early using System.exit.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the `finally` block?

choices.label: To catch exceptions that the catch blocks missed.
choices.text: To catch exceptions that the catch blocks missed.

choices.label: To release resources, such as files or database connections.
choices.text: To release resources, such as files or database connections.

choices.label: To retry the code in the try block if it fails.
choices.text: To retry the code in the try block if it fails.

choices.label: To print the stack trace to the console.
choices.text: To print the stack trace to the console.

questions.explanation: Because a finally block almost always executes, it is the ideal place for resource-release code to avoid resource leaks.

questions.text: Which statement regarding try blocks is true?

choices.label: Local variables declared in a try block can be accessed in its catch blocks.
choices.text: Local variables declared in a try block can be accessed in its catch blocks.

choices.label: A try block must be followed by at least one catch block or a finally block.
choices.text: A try block must be followed by at least one catch block or a finally block.

choices.label: A try block can catch exceptions without needing catch blocks.
choices.text: A try block can catch exceptions without needing catch blocks.

choices.label: Code can be placed between a try block and its catch blocks.
choices.text: Code can be placed between a try block and its catch blocks.

questions.explanation: A try block must be followed by at least one catch block or a finally block. Local variables in the try block go out of scope when the block finishes.

questions.text: Which stream is specifically recommended for outputting error messages in Java?

choices.label: System.out
choices.text: System.out

choices.label: System.in
choices.text: System.in

choices.label: System.err
choices.text: System.err

choices.label: System.log
choices.text: System.log

questions.explanation: The text demonstrates using System.err (standard error stream) to output error messages.

questions.text: What is the primary characteristic of the `finally` block in Java exception handling?

choices.label: It executes only if an exception occurs.
choices.text: It executes only if an exception occurs.

choices.label: It executes only if no exception occurs.
choices.text: It executes only if no exception occurs.

choices.label: It executes regardless of whether an exception occurs or is caught.
choices.text: It executes regardless of whether an exception occurs or is caught.

choices.label: It is used to catch checked exceptions specifically.
choices.text: It is used to catch checked exceptions specifically.

questions.explanation: The finally block is designed to execute regardless of whether an exception is thrown or caught, making it ideal for resource deallocation.

questions.text: According to the text, what happens if an exception is thrown in a `finally` block while another exception is already pending (not yet caught)?

choices.label: The original exception is preserved and the new one is suppressed.
choices.text: The original exception is preserved and the new one is suppressed.

choices.label: Both exceptions are combined into a Multi-Exception object.
choices.text: Both exceptions are combined into a Multi-Exception object.

choices.label: The original exception is lost and the new exception is returned to the calling method.
choices.text: The original exception is lost and the new exception is returned to the calling method.

choices.label: The program enters an infinite loop.
choices.text: The program enters an infinite loop.

questions.explanation: Common Programming Error 11.6 states that if the finally block throws an exception that is not caught, the first exception will be lost.

questions.text: How do you rethrow an exception in Java?

choices.label: By calling `exception.rethrow()`.
choices.text: By calling `exception.rethrow()`.

choices.label: By using the `throw` keyword followed by the exception object reference inside a `catch` block.
choices.text: By using the `throw` keyword followed by the exception object reference inside a `catch` block.

choices.label: By placing the exception object in the `finally` block.
choices.text: By placing the exception object in the `finally` block.

choices.label: Exceptions cannot be rethrown once caught.
choices.text: Exceptions cannot be rethrown once caught.

questions.explanation: An exception is rethrown using the `throw` keyword followed by the reference to the exception object caught in the catch block.

questions.text: Which stream is specifically designed to display a program's errors, allowing them to be redirected independently of standard output?

choices.label: System.out
choices.text: System.out

choices.label: System.in
choices.text: System.in

choices.label: System.err
choices.text: System.err

choices.label: System.log
choices.text: System.log

questions.explanation: System.err is the standard error stream, which allows error messages to be separated from standard output (System.out).

questions.text: What can be the operand of a `throw` statement?

choices.label: Any String message.
choices.text: Any String message.

choices.label: Any object of a class derived from Throwable.
choices.text: Any object of a class derived from Throwable.

choices.label: Only objects of the class Exception.
choices.text: Only objects of the class Exception.

choices.label: Any primitive data type.
choices.text: Any primitive data type.

questions.explanation: The operand of a throw statement must be an instance of Throwable or one of its subclasses.

questions.text: What is 'stack unwinding'?

choices.label: The process of allocating memory for a new method call.
choices.text: The process of allocating memory for a new method call.

choices.label: The process where a method terminates and control returns to the caller when an exception is not caught in the current scope.
choices.text: The process where a method terminates and control returns to the caller when an exception is not caught in the current scope.

choices.label: A technique to optimize recursive method calls.
choices.text: A technique to optimize recursive method calls.

choices.label: Clearing the stack trace to hide error details.
choices.text: Clearing the stack trace to hide error details.

questions.explanation: Stack unwinding occurs when an exception is thrown but not caught in a scope; the current method terminates, local variables go out of scope, and the stack is searched for an outer try block.

questions.text: Which method of class `Throwable` returns an array of objects representing the method-call stack?

choices.label: `getMessage()`
choices.text: `getMessage()`

choices.label: `printStackTrace()`
choices.text: `printStackTrace()`

choices.label: `getStackTrace()`
choices.text: `getStackTrace()`

choices.label: `getStackTraceArray()`
choices.text: `getStackTraceArray()`

questions.explanation: The `getStackTrace()` method retrieves stack-trace information as an array of StackTraceElement objects.

questions.text: What information is typically provided by Java's default exception handler when an exception is not caught?

choices.label: Only the line number of the error.
choices.text: Only the line number of the error.

choices.label: The name of the exception, a descriptive message, and a complete stack trace.
choices.text: The name of the exception, a descriptive message, and a complete stack trace.

choices.label: A prompt for the user to debug the code manually.
choices.text: A prompt for the user to debug the code manually.

choices.label: The values of all local variables at the time of the error.
choices.text: The values of all local variables at the time of the error.

questions.explanation: As per Error-Prevention Tip 11.6, the default handler displays the exception name, a descriptive message, and the stack trace.

choices.label: The main method that calls method3.
choices.text: The main method that calls method3.

choices.label: The catch block in the main method.
choices.text: The catch block in the main method.

choices.label: Line 49, where the exception is instantiated and thrown.
choices.text: Line 49, where the exception is instantiated and thrown.

choices.label: The finally block associated with method3.
choices.text: The finally block associated with method3.

questions.explanation: The throw point is the specific statement where the exception occurs or is explicitly thrown.

questions.text: Which `StackTraceElement` method returns the name of the method containing the execution point represented by the element?

choices.label: `getClassName()`
choices.text: `getClassName()`

choices.label: `getFileName()`
choices.text: `getFileName()`

choices.label: `getLineNumber()`
choices.text: `getLineNumber()`

choices.label: `getMethodName()`
choices.text: `getMethodName()`

questions.explanation: The `getMethodName()` method of the StackTraceElement class returns the name of the method.

questions.text: What is the purpose of 'Chained Exceptions'?

choices.label: To allow a single catch block to handle multiple unrelated exceptions.
choices.text: To allow a single catch block to handle multiple unrelated exceptions.

choices.label: To maintain the complete stack-trace information of an original exception when a new exception type is thrown.
choices.text: To maintain the complete stack-trace information of an original exception when a new exception type is thrown.

choices.label: To force a finally block to execute multiple times.
choices.text: To force a finally block to execute multiple times.

choices.label: To link multiple catch blocks together for better performance.
choices.text: To link multiple catch blocks together for better performance.

questions.explanation: Chained exceptions allow an exception to wrap an underlying cause, preserving the original stack trace for debugging.

questions.text: When creating a custom exception class, what is the recommended naming convention?

choices.label: Start the name with 'Error'.
choices.text: Start the name with 'Error'.

choices.label: The name should end with the word 'Exception'.
choices.text: The name should end with the word 'Exception'.

choices.label: The name should be all capital letters.
choices.text: The name should be all capital letters.

choices.label: Use the prefix 'Java'.
choices.text: Use the prefix 'Java'.

questions.explanation: Good Programming Practice 11.4 states that by convention, all exception-class names should end with the word Exception.

questions.text: A new exception class should extend `RuntimeException` if:

choices.label: The client application should be required to handle it.
choices.text: The client application should be required to handle it.

choices.label: The exception is a checked exception.
choices.text: The exception is a checked exception.

choices.label: The client code should be able to ignore the exception (unchecked exception).
choices.text: The client code should be able to ignore the exception (unchecked exception).

choices.label: It occurs due to external factors like file system errors.
choices.text: It occurs due to external factors like file system errors.

questions.explanation: Extending RuntimeException creates an unchecked exception, which the compiler does not force the programmer to catch or declare.

questions.text: Why should you avoid an empty `catch` handler body?

choices.label: It will cause a compilation error.
choices.text: It will cause a compilation error.

choices.label: It slows down the program's execution.
choices.text: It slows down the program's execution.

choices.label: It effectively ignores the exception, making debugging very difficult.
choices.text: It effectively ignores the exception, making debugging very difficult.

choices.label: Empty catch blocks are only allowed for checked exceptions.
choices.text: Empty catch blocks are only allowed for checked exceptions.

questions.explanation: Software Engineering Observation 11.10 warns that an empty catch block swallows the error, hiding problems from the developer.

questions.text: Which constructor is NOT typically found in a custom exception class?

choices.label: One that takes no arguments and uses a default message.
choices.text: One that takes no arguments and uses a default message.

choices.label: One that takes a String message and a Throwable cause.
choices.text: One that takes a String message and a Throwable cause.

choices.label: One that takes a Throwable cause only.
choices.text: One that takes a Throwable cause only.

choices.label: One that takes an integer error code only.
choices.text: One that takes an integer error code only.

questions.explanation: Standard custom exceptions typically provide constructors for no-args, String message, String + Throwable, and Throwable.

questions.text: What happens when an `assert` statement evaluates to `false`?

choices.label: A message is printed to System.out, but the program continues.
choices.text: A message is printed to System.out, but the program continues.

choices.label: A checked exception is thrown.
choices.text: A checked exception is thrown.

choices.label: An `AssertionError` is thrown.
choices.text: An `AssertionError` is thrown.

choices.label: The JVM automatically restarts the method.
choices.text: The JVM automatically restarts the method.

questions.explanation: The assert statement evaluates a boolean and throws an AssertionError if it is false.

questions.text: Which command-line option is used to enable assertions at runtime?

choices.label: `-assertions:on`
choices.text: `-assertions:on`

choices.label: `-ea`
choices.text: `-ea`

choices.label: `-debug`
choices.text: `-debug`

choices.label: `-check`
choices.text: `-check`

questions.explanation: The `-ea` (enable assertions) flag must be passed to the java command to process assert statements.

questions.text: What is a 'precondition' in method design?

choices.label: A condition that is true after the method finishes.
choices.text: A condition that is true after the method finishes.

choices.label: A constraint on parameters or the program state that must be true before the method is invoked.
choices.text: A constraint on parameters or the program state that must be true before the method is invoked.

choices.label: A block of code that runs before the try block.
choices.text: A block of code that runs before the try block.

choices.label: A requirement for compiling the class.
choices.text: A requirement for compiling the class.

questions.explanation: Preconditions describe expectations about the program state just before a method begins execution.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct syntax for the Java SE 7 multi-catch feature?

choices.label: `catch (Type1, Type2 e)`
choices.text: `catch (Type1, Type2 e)`

choices.label: `catch (Type1 e1, Type2 e2)`
choices.text: `catch (Type1 e1, Type2 e2)`

choices.label: `catch (Type1 | Type2 e)`
choices.text: `catch (Type1 | Type2 e)`

choices.label: `catch (Type1 : Type2 e)`
choices.text: `catch (Type1 : Type2 e)`

questions.explanation: In a multi-catch, exception types are separated by a vertical bar (|).

questions.text: What requirement must an object meet to be used in a `try-with-resources` statement?

choices.label: It must be a primitive type.
choices.text: It must be a primitive type.

choices.label: It must implement the `AutoCloseable` interface.
choices.text: It must implement the `AutoCloseable` interface.

choices.label: It must be declared as `final`.
choices.text: It must be declared as `final`.

choices.label: It must have a constructor that takes no arguments.
choices.text: It must have a constructor that takes no arguments.

questions.explanation: Each resource in a try-with-resources statement must implement AutoCloseable, which defines the `close()` method called automatically.
